title: Part 3
content:
Part 3

AFTER ABOUT AN hour, I faced Sakayanagi.

How outsiders unrelated to the White Room felt about today's results—it was an invaluable opportunity to find out, needless to say.

"Let me hear your opinion again. Of course, there's no need to hold back."

"That's right. I've been thinking all day while watching the children's growth."

The significance of the White Room, the utility of the White Room—could Sakayanagi feel it firsthand?

"The children I saw today were far removed from the average three-year-olds I know. The children Suzukake-san educated, and even those by Ishida-san and Souya-san, are probably superior to 90% of the children in this world."

Sakayanagi's characteristic, to start with praise, hadn't changed.

"Even with wealthy families' elite education, it wouldn't be easy to reach this level."

"But from your tone, they can't compete with the remaining 10%?"

"Isn't that something you felt firsthand, Ayanokouji-sensei?"

The children, now three years old, had almost certainly developed intelligence and physical abilities beyond average children.

Certain results had been achieved.

However, the world would still harbor doubts, and I didn't think it was enough to dispel them.

If asked whether these three-year-olds were equal or superior to the so-called gifted, it would be a gray area.

Waiting for the first group of children to turn four or five wouldn't be decisive.

"However, I think this is sufficient. If we can provide such thorough education to children who might not receive the education they need, they can acquire enough skills to function in society."

That was Sakayanagi's overall assessment, unaware of the true nature of the White Room.

"That's why placing Suzukake-san as the leader gave me a hint of unease. Emotions are essential for children… no, for humans. Nobody can exist without joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure. If you can correct that notion, I wouldn't hesitate to continue to support and assist you."

"I see. I thought you would say that. However, do you think the current investors as well as the businessmen we've yet to meet will be satisfied? Not everyone thinks only of the children like you do. There are significant interests involved in this White Room."

"Is a more rigorous education necessary?"

"Yes. Anyone can produce geniuses if they have a certain amount of money. Just hire lecturers from top universities and coaches who have produced Olympic athletes. If you give children an elite education from a young age and maintain it, most of them will be able to enhance their skills to a certain extent. A White Room that only produces similar results bears no significance. It has no value."

Who would invest millions, or even billions in the White Room?

"What's needed are exceptional abilities—a brain that can surpass Japan's top universities and win at the world's prestigious schools, physical abilities beyond Olympic athletes, and an indomitable spirit that doesn't flinch even against world leaders. That's the power the White Room needs."

"Isn't that excessive charity? Not all children who are abandoned or without parents seek such power. It's enough to give them the ability to adapt and live in society."

"I understand what you're trying to say. Your opinion will sufficiently act as a reference."

"…Ayanokouji-sensei, what you told me, it's true, right?"

"Of course. I am working to rescue disadvantaged children. You know I have my ambitions, but it's neither more nor less than that."

Sakayanagi, who had looked doubtful, slightly bowed his head in apology.

"Then, I have nothing more to say. Please provide an education full of love, considering the children first. Then, the day will come when the citizens recognize the White Room."

With that, Sakayanagi left the office. His face showed he wasn't convinced.

"How naive, Sakayanagi. That won't do."

The world wouldn't accept such idealism alone.

What was demanded wasn't just any result, but the best result.

However, it still wasn't enough.

One more push. Just one more push was needed.

There was no guarantee that the investors would keep nodding their heads with the current results. Something to shove their backs forward…

A decisive factor was needed.

However, imposing stricter education on the children now wouldn't yield immediate results.

Three years… no, five years… We needed to wait at least that long.

I needed to create persuasive power.

What should I do…?

How can I get the financial world to put in more money in such a short period of time?

Think, keep thinking…

This White Room might change the world.

I wanted my words to carry weight.

Weight… huh?

"…I see."

I remembered what Naoe-sensei had said here.

Without sacrificing yourself, there was no true success.

No matter how passionately I discussed our education's success or failure, my words wouldn't truly carry weight. The financial world also didn't trust the White Room.

And why was that?

It was obvious—it was always someone else's education.

It wouldn't hurt me.

This was merely an extension of play.

I needed to show a solid reason why they could entrust their precious children to the White Room.

There was only one thing I needed to do.

I picked up my phone and made a call to a certain person.

"…Hello?"

It was evening now, and the person on the phone, who was probably asleep, answered with a groggy voice.

"Mika. I have a favor to ask of you."
